title: Haakon Sørbye
text:
Haakon Sørbye (16 March 1920 – 15 September 2016) was a Norwegian engineer and <a href="Norwegian%20resistance%20movement">resistance</a> member during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He was a member of the radio group <a href="Skylark%20B">Skylark B</a> during the war. After the war he was a professor at the <a href="Norwegian%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Norwegian Institute of Technology</a>.
World War II.
Sørbye attended secondary school at <a href="Stabekk">Stabekk</a>, and enrolled at the <a href="Norwegian%20Institute%20of%20Technology">Norwegian Institute of Technology</a> on 1 September 1939 — the day <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> began. In April 1940, the war reached Norway, with <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a> <a href="Operation%20Weser%C3%BCbung">invading</a> and <a href="occupation%20of%20Norway%20by%20Nazi%20Germany">occupying the country</a>. Sørbye participated in the <a href="Norwegian%20Campaign">Norwegian Campaign</a> as a telegrapher, but the Norwegian forces in <a href="Tr%C3%B8ndelag">Trøndelag</a> capitulated by 10 May 1940.
In September 1940, the British <a href="Secret%20Intelligence%20Service">Secret Intelligence Service</a> established two stations for radio communication in occupied Norway; the so-called <a href="Skylark%20A">Skylark A</a> was led by <a href="Sverre%20Midtskau">Sverre Midtskau</a> in Oslo while <a href="Skylark%20B">Skylark B</a> was led by <a href="Erik%20Welle-Strand">Erik Welle-Strand</a> in <a href="Trondheim">Trondheim</a>. As students formed the backbone of the Skylark B group, Sørbye joined. Other members were <a href="Bj%C3%B8rn%20R%C3%B8rholt">Bjørn Rørholt</a> and <a href="Einar%20Johansen">Einar Johansen</a>. Chemistry professor <a href="Leif%20Tronstad">Leif Tronstad</a> also helped as well. <a href="Egil%20Reksten">Egil Reksten</a> later took over as leader. Skylark B established regular contact with the intelligence in London in 1941 and helped provide information on German troop and naval movements, as well as vital information about <a href="Wehrmacht">German</a> activity at the <a href="Vemork">Vemork</a> <a href="heavy%20water">heavy water</a> plant.
In September 1941, however, <a href="Gestapo">Gestapo</a> managed to track the Skylark B transmitting activity. Sørbye was arrested by the Nazi authorities, and was first held in <a href="Vollan%20prison">Vollan prison</a>. He was then incarcerated at <a href="M%C3%B8llergata%2019">Møllergata 19</a> from 27 September 1941 to 16 January 1943, and then at <a href="Grini%20concentration%20camp">Grini concentration camp</a> until 29 July 1943. He was then shipped to Germany and the <a href="Nacht%20und%20Nebel">Nacht und Nebel</a> camps. He spent much time in <a href="Natzweiler-Struthof">Natzweiler</a>. Despite health problems, he survived until the end of World War II, and was brought home with the <a href="White%20Buses">White Buses</a>. Reksten survived as well, but seven of the eleven detainees associated with Skylark died. Sørbye was decorated with the <a href="King%27s%20Medal%20for%20Courage%20in%20the%20Cause%20of%20Freedom">King's Medal for Courage in the Cause of Freedom</a> and the <a href="Defence%20Medal%201940%E2%80%931945">Defence Medal 1940–1945</a>.
Post-war life.
Sørbye resumed his studies, and finally graduated from the Norwegian Institute of Technology in 1948. He was hired by the <a href="Norwegian%20Defence%20Research%20Establishment">Norwegian Defence Research Establishment</a>, and stationed at their radar in Bergen. During the 1950s he stayed abroad to research; at the <a href="Post%20Office%20Research%20Station">UK Post Office Research Station</a> in 1951 and the <a href="SHAPE%20Technical%20Centre">SHAPE Air Defence Technical Centre</a> (SADTC) from 1957 to 1960. In 1964 he was hired as a lecturer in telephone technology at the Norwegian Institute of Technology. After a period as professor of communication technology at the Technische Hogeschool Twente (nowadays: <a href="University%20of%20Twente">University of Twente</a>) from 1970 to 1972, he was a professor of <a href="telematics">telematics</a> at the Norwegian Institute of Technology from 1972 to his retirement in 1987. He was a fellow of the <a href="Norwegian%20Academy%20of%20Technological%20Sciences">Norwegian Academy of Technological Sciences</a>.
After his retirement he has spent much time as a guide with the White Buses, work for which he was awarded a <a href="King%27s%20Medal%20of%20Merit">King's Medal of Merit</a> in 2015. He also practised as a <a href="Amateur%20radio">radio amateur</a>. His wife Ruth was a skilled geologist. Sørbye died on 15 September 2016.
